title: A Visualisation Approach for Collaborative Planning Systems Based on Ontologies

references.raw: Lino, N., Tate, A., Siebra, C. and Chen-Burger, Y. 2003. references.raw: Tate, A. 2001. I-X and <I-N-C-A>: an Architecture and Related Ontology for Mixed-Initiative Synthesis Tasks, In Proceedings of the Workshop on Planning/ Scheduling and Configuration/Design, Vienna, Austria.

references.raw: Tate,  A.  and  Drabble,  B.  1995.  O-Plan' s  PlanWorld Viewers. In Proceedings of the Fourteenth UK Special Interest  Group  on  Planning  and  Scheduling,  Wivenhoe House Conference Centre, Essex University.

references.title: Ontology-based Information Visualisation.
references.raw: Fluit, C., Sabou, M., Harmelen, F. 2002. Ontology-based Information Visualisation. In Proceedings of Visualising the  Semantic  Web  -  VSW  2002.  Springer  Verlag, Vladimir Geroimenko Editor, pp. 546-0554.

references.title: The Limits of Speech Recognition.
references.raw: Shneiderman,  B.  2000.  The  Limits  of  Speech Recognition. In Communications of the ACM, Vol. 43, No. 9, pp. 63-65, September, 2000.

references.title: Trains-95: Towards a mixed-initiative planning assistant.
references.raw: Ferguson, G., and Allen, J. 1996. Trains-95: Towards a mixed-initiative  planning  assistant.  In  Proceedings Artificial Intelligence Planning Systems, pp. 70-77.

references.title: Trips: An intelligent integrated problem-solving assistant.
references.raw: Ferguson, G., and Allen, J. 1998. Trips: An intelligent integrated  problem-solving  assistant.  In  Proceedings AAAI-98, pp. 567-573.

references.title: Visualisation of RDF(S)-based Information.
references.raw: Telea, A., Frasincar, F., Houben, G. 2003. Visualisation of  RDF(S)-based  Information.  In  Proceedings  of  the Seventh  International  Conference  on  Information Visualization - IV 2003, pp. 294-299, London, England.

abstract:
The University of Edinburgh and research sponsors are authorised to reproduce and distribute reprints and on-line copies for their purposes notwithstanding any copyright annotation hereon.  The views and conclusions contained herein are the author’s and shouldn’t be interpreted as necessarily representing the official policies or endorsements, either expressed or implied, of other parties.In the last decades, many advances have been made in intelligent planning systems. Significant improvements related to core problems, providing faster search algorithms and shortest plans have been proposed.\ud
However, there is a lack in researches allowing a better support for a proper use and interaction with planners, where, for instance, visualization can play an important\ud
role. This work proposes a way to address the problem of visualization in intelligent planning systems via a more general approach. It consists in an integrated ontology set and reasoning mechanism for multi-modality\ud
visualisation destined to collaborative planning environments. This framework will permit organizing and modeling the domain from the visualization perspective, and give a tailored support for presentation\ud
of information

A Visualisation Approach for Collaborative Planning Systems Based on Ontologies</dc:title><dc:creator>
Lino, N</dc:creator><dc:creator>
Tate, Austin</dc:creator><dc:contributor>
CAPES Foundation</dc:contributor><dc:subject>
Informatics</dc:subject><dc:subject>

ontologies</dc:subject><dc:subject>
artificial intelligence</dc:subject><dc:subject>
visualisation</dc:subject><dc:subject>
intelligent planning</dc:subject><dc:subject>
Artificial Intelligence Applications Institute</dc:subject><dc:description>
The University of Edinburgh and research sponsors are authorised to reproduce and distribute reprints and on-line copies for their purposes notwithstanding any copyright annotation hereon.  The views and conclusions contained herein are the author’s and shouldn’t be interpreted as necessarily representing the official policies or endorsements, either expressed or implied, of other parties.</dc:description><dc:description>
In the last decades, many advances have been made in intelligent planning systems. Significant improvements related to core problems, providing faster search algorithms and shortest plans have been proposed.\ud
However, there is a lack in researches allowing a better support for a proper use and interaction with planners, where, for instance, visualization can play an important\ud
role. This work proposes a way to address the problem of visualization in intelligent planning systems via a more general approach. It consists in an integrated ontology set and reasoning mechanism for multi-modality\ud
visualisation destined to collaborative planning environments. This framework will permit organizing and modeling the domain from the visualization perspective, and give a tailored support for presentation\ud
of information.</dc:description><dc:date>
